content:
@Eric Wieser nerdsniped me into thinking about in what generality "row rank of a matrix equals column rank" is true. We have docs#matrix.rank for general commutative rings and (A : matrix m n R) : Aᵀ.rank = A.rank makes sense for m and n both fintypes.

So whatever is the rank of a matrix over a commutative ring RRR? It's defined to be the rank of the image of the corresponding linear map, which is a finitely-generated RRR-module. If R=0R=0R=0 then there's only one finitely-generated RRR-module so it's true in this case. For RRR nonzero, the rank r(M)r(M)r(M) of an RRR-module MMM is defined to be the sup of the ranks of the free submodules of MMM. If M→NM\to NM→N is injective then r(M)≤r(N)r(M)\leq r(N)r(M)≤r(N) (obvious) and if M→NM\to NM→N is surjective then r(M)≥r(N)r(M)\geq r(N)r(M)≥r(N) (you can lift a free submodule of NNN back to MMM by lifting generators), so at least rrr isn't completely pathological, and in particular the rank of an RRR-module which is generated by ddd elements is at most ddd. But for general RRR this is pretty much all one can say; rank is not additive even for direct sums, for example (if R=A⊕BR=A\oplus BR=A⊕B is the sum of two fields then r(A)=r(B)=0r(A)=r(B)=0r(A)=r(B)=0 but r(R)=1r(R)=1r(R)=1).

This definition of rank was basically invented by the mathlib community, I think, and doesn't seem to be in the literature (perhaps because it's so poorly-behaved). If RRR is an integral domain then the definition is in the literature and the function is better-behaved. Here is what I think should be a proof of row rank = column rank for integral domains: first show that if KKK is the field of fractions of RRR then rR(M)=rK(K⊗RM)r_R(M)=r_K(K\otimes_RM)rR​(M)=rK​(K⊗R​M) which reduces the question to fields and then for fields it's a standard result (proof by elementary row operations or whatever). I assume the equality is true. Perhaps one route (probably not the shortest) to it would be to first show that if R→SR\to SR→S is an injection of commutative rings and MMM is an SSS-module then rR(M)=rS(M)r_R(M)=r_S(M)rR​(M)=rS​(M); this would follow from the facts that if Sd⊆MS^d\subseteq MSd⊆M then obviously Rd⊆MR^d\subseteq MRd⊆M, and conversely if Rd⊆MR^d\subseteq MRd⊆M then I am assuming one can use a basis to get Sd⊆MS^d\subseteq MSd⊆M although I don't immediately see why the map is injective. Then one could presumably show that rR(M)=rR(M⊗RK)r_R(M)=r_R(M\otimes_RK)rR​(M)=rR​(M⊗R​K) for RRR an integral domain and KKK its field of fractions. I should say that I have checked none of this and am just going by intuition, which might be wrong.

As I say, I think that for RRR not an integral domain, our definition is not in the literature. What is in the literature is the function on X:=Spec(R)X:=\mathrm{Spec}(R)X:=Spec(R) sending a prime ideal PPP to the RP/PRPR_P/PR_PRP​/PRP​-dimension of MP/PMPM_P/PM_PMP​/PMP​. For RRR reduced, our rank function might be the min of this function on XXX, although unfortunately this does not seem to be true in general; for example if R=Z/p2ZR=\Z/p^2\ZR=Z/p2Z for ppp prime, or R=C[ϵ]/(ϵ2)R=\mathbb{C}[\epsilon]/(\epsilon^2)R=C[ϵ]/(ϵ2) then RRR is local with maximal ideal mmm and rR(R/m)=0r_R(R/m)=0rR​(R/m)=0, whereas the function in the literature takes the value 1. So if one were to approach the question via the standard alegebraic geometry "reduction" techniques (which I've already hinted at, by suggesting that the result can be proved for integral domains given that it's true for fields) then one has to get around this hurdle somehow. If it's true that for R⊆SR\subseteq SR⊆S then rR(M)=rS(M⊗RS)r_R(M)=r_S(M\otimes_RS)rR​(M)=rS​(M⊗R​S) then I guess one can reduce to the Noetherian case; I then don't know how to reduce to the case where RRR is reduced, but once you're there then maybe our function is the min of the function on XXX and then perhaps one can prove the general case (if it's true) by arguing on points.
(for reference, #18818 has a proof of the titular fact, but under fairly unreasonable requirements; though I suggest we don't discuss that PR here)

The PR seems to suggest that proving row rank = column rank would require Gaussian elimination, but at least for fields, we seem to already have the result in docs#linear_map.finrank_range_dual_map_eq_finrank_range. It's fairly straightforward to combine that with docs#matrix.to_lin_transpose to get the desired result for matrices:

theorem matrix.rank_transpose' {𝕜 i j : Type*}
  [field 𝕜] [fintype i] [fintype j] (m : matrix i j 𝕜) :
  m.transpose.rank = m.rank :=
begin
  classical,
  rw [m.transpose.rank_eq_finrank_range_to_lin (pi.basis_fun 𝕜 j).dual_basis (pi.basis_fun 𝕜 i).dual_basis,
      matrix.to_lin_transpose, ← linear_map.dual_map_def, linear_map.finrank_range_dual_map_eq_finrank_range, matrix.to_lin_eq_to_lin',
      matrix.to_lin'_apply', matrix.rank],
end

(Note: I'm not sure why docs#matrix.to_lin_transpose states the result using docs#module.dual.transpose instead of docs#linear_map.dual_map. Why even bother having the latter if lemma statements will use transpose f instead of f.dual_map?)

This would at least prove the "standard undergrad" version of the result, and is useful for the many times when you have to do linear algebra over a finite field in TCS.
